reason: INCOMPLETE CASE ANALYSIS: Sub-case A considers '1 and 4 in same block' but ONLY handles the situation where g_2 FIXES that block. What happens if 1 and 4 are in the same block g_1^j(B) but g_2(g_1^j(B)) \!= g_1^j(B)? In this case, g_2 maps the block containing {1,4} to a different block. This sub-sub-case is not analyzed. The statement says 'If g_2 fixes g_1^j(B), then...' but never addresses the alternative where g_2 does NOT fix it.
